<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 235, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 599, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 402]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 416]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 505]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 549]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 695, 104, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 695, 719, 714]]<|/det|>
When the volcano Krakatoa erupted in 1883, it was heard 5000 km away.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 725, 663, 744]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the sound from the volcano is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 753, 133, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 753, 922, 789]]<|/det|>
If such a loud sound were to be made today, an astronaut orbiting in space (a vacuum) at a height of \(400\mathrm{km}\) could hear it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 794, 131, 813]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 794, 880, 814]]<|/det|>
People further from the volcano heard the sound later than people nearer to the volcano.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 821, 131, 839]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 821, 856, 841]]<|/det|>
The amplitude of the sound waves would have been smaller further from the volcano.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 847, 133, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 847, 880, 866]]<|/det|>
The sound was very loud because a lot of energy was transferred to vibrations of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 808, 91]]<|/det|> A loudspeaker on a boat produces a pulse of sound in the sea. The echo of the pulse <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 85, 730, 106]]<|/det|> back at the boat after 3.0 s. The depth of the sea under the boat is 2250 m. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 112, 650, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 672, 317]]<|/det|> From this information, what is the speed of sound in the sea water? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 133, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 327, 225, 345]]<|/det|> 330 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 327, 300, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 327, 396, 345]]<|/det|> 750 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 327, 467, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 327, 570, 345]]<|/det|> 1500 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 327, 636, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 327, 737, 345]]<|/det|> 6750 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 370, 104, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 370, 685, 389]]<|/det|> A hard magnetic material can be used to make a permanent magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 401, 672, 420]]<|/det|> A soft magnetic material can be used to make a temporary magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 431, 754, 450]]<|/det|> Which row shows whether iron and steel are hard or soft magnetic materials? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 460, 351, 591]]<|/det|>
ironsteel
Ahardhard
Bhardsoft

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 617, 106, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 617, 526, 636]]<|/det|> How can a permanent magnet be demagnetised? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 647, 133, 665]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 647, 410, 665]]<|/det|> cool the magnet for a long time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 672, 133, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 672, 492, 689]]<|/det|> hit the magnet repeatedly with a hammer <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 698, 133, 715]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 698, 626, 715]]<|/det|> leave the magnet in a coil which is connected to a battery <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 724, 133, 742]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 724, 432, 742]]<|/det|> shine bright light onto the magnet <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 769, 106, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 769, 705, 787]]<|/det|> Which equation can be used to calculate the resistance \(R\) of a resistor? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 797, 133, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 797, 732, 816]]<|/det|> \(V = I \div R\) \(I = V \times R\) \(R = V \times I\) \(V = I \times R\)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[744, 976, 967, 997]]<|/det|>
# <label>IPA</label> <label>CAMBRIDGE</label>
